content: The Employee Participation Incentive Act of 1998 is also known as the Act. It sets the maximum rate of income tax for C corporations with substantial employee ownership. The Employee Participation Incentive Act of 1998, also known as the Act, amends the Internal Revenue Code to set a maximum tax rate of 30 percent for C corporations with substantial employee ownership. This applies if the employee voting percentage and employee value percentage are both at least 20 percent. The Employee Ownership Percentage is defined as the lesser of the employee voting percentage or the employee value percentage in a corporation. Employee voting percentage refers to the voting power of stock held by employees, while employee value percentage refers to the total value of stock held by employees. The term "stock" is defined under section 1504. The determination of employee voting percentage and employee value percentage is made on the last day of the corporation's taxable year. Highly compensated employees and 5 percent shareholders are disregarded in calculating these percentages, except for 5-percent owners if the corporation has a certain number of employees. Controlled groups are also taken into account. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998 for corporations treated as a single employer under section 52(a). Controlled groups are treated as 1 corporation for certain purposes, with regulations prescribed by the Secretary to prevent abuse of this provision. SEC. 3. EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME FOR COMPENSATION PAID IN STOCK BY CERTAIN CORPORATIONS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a new section, SEC. 139, regarding compensation paid in stock by certain corporations. SEC. 139 excludes remuneration in the form of stock from an eligible corporation's employee's gross income, limited to 20% of wages. Eligible corporation defined as one offering stock as remuneration for services. SEC. 139 allows for the exclusion of stock remuneration from an eligible corporation's employee's gross income, up to 20% of wages. The stock must be offered to at least 95% of full-time employees, with 95% of the value offered to employees in the bottom 75% of wages. This exclusion does not affect the basis of the stock. Additionally, stock remuneration is excluded from withholding under section 3401 of the Code.
